metadata.title: Supporting Information Specific Recognition of Proteins by Array-Bound Hexanucleotides**

body_text.text: Several blocking solutions were tested in order to increase the ratio between signal and noise and to avoid degradation of the immobilized oligonucleotides. Best results were obtained with 2% (w/v) casein (Sigma, Taufkirchen, Germany) in binding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 5 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl 2 ). Arrays were incubated with blocking solution (1 ml per array) 4 h at room temperature, followed by washing 5 times with binding buffer. Next, 500 µl to 1000 µl fluorescently labelled protein diluted in binding buffer was added to the arrays and incubated for 2 min at room temperature.

The arrays were washed again five times with binding buffer, and fixed by incubating the array for 10 sec in acetone or ethanol. After drying the arrays were scanned using a Typhoon 8600 scanner (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, USA).

Typically, radiolabelled oligonucleotides (1 nM) and target protein (5 -25 µM) were incubated in 30 µl of binding buffer (50 mM Tris/HCl pH 8.0, 5 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl 2 and 1 mM DTT) for 2 min at 25°C. An aliquot (10 µl) of this mixture was soaked through a pre-rinsed nitro-cellulose filter BA85 (Schleicher & Schuell, Dassel, Germany) and rinsed with 3 ml of binding buffer. Radioactivity retained on the filters was measured by scintillation counting (PerkinElmer, Boston, MA, USA).

Oligonucleotides were co-transfected by calciumphosphate co-precipitation with pGJ3-Luci and pczVSV-G in 10 6 293T cells as described.
